1.verse: I. Title and Introduction Chapter 1 Purpose of the Proverbs of Solomon - The proverbs of Solomon, the son of David, king of Israel:

2.verse: That people may know wisdom and discipline, may understand intelligent sayings;

3.verse: May receive instruction in wise conduct, in what is right, just and fair;

4.verse: That resourcefulness may be imparted to the naive, knowledge and discretion to the young.

5.verse: The wise by hearing them will advance in learning, the intelligent will gain sound guidance,

6.verse: To comprehend proverb and byword, the words of the wise and their riddles.

7.verse: Fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and discipline.

8.verse: II. Instructions of Parents and of Woman Wisdom The Path of the Wicked: Greed and Violence - Hear, my son, your father’s instruction, and reject not your mother’s teaching;

9.verse: A graceful diadem will they be for your head; a pendant for your neck.

10.verse: My son, should sinners entice you,

11.verse: do not go if they say, “Come along with us! Let us lie in wait for blood, unprovoked, let us trap the innocent;

12.verse: Let us swallow them alive, like Sheol, whole, like those who go down to the pit!

13.verse: All kinds of precious wealth shall we gain, we shall fill our houses with booty;

14.verse: Cast in your lot with us, we shall all have one purse!”

15.verse: My son, do not walk in the way with them, hold back your foot from their path!

16.verse: [For their feet run to evil, they hasten to shed blood.]

17.verse: In vain a net is spread right under the eyes of any bird—

18.verse: They lie in wait for their own blood, they set a trap for their own lives.

19.verse: This is the way of everyone greedy for loot: it takes away their lives.

20.verse: Wisdom in Person Gives a Warning - Wisdom cries aloud in the street, in the open squares she raises her voice;

21.verse: Down the crowded ways she calls out, at the city gates she utters her words:

22.verse: “How long, you naive ones, will you love naivete,

23.verse: How long will you turn away at my reproof? [The arrogant delight in their arrogance, and fools hate knowledge.] Lo! I will pour out to you my spirit, I will acquaint you with my words:

24.verse: ‘Because I called and you refused, extended my hand and no one took notice;

25.verse: Because you disdained all my counsel, and my reproof you ignored—

26.verse: I, in my turn, will laugh at your doom; will mock when terror overtakes you;

27.verse: When terror comes upon you like a storm, and your doom approaches like a whirlwind; when distress and anguish befall you.’

28.verse: Then they will call me, but I will not answer; they will seek me, but will not find me,

29.verse: Because they hated knowledge, and the fear of the LORD they did not choose.

30.verse: They ignored my counsel, they spurned all my reproof;

31.verse: Well, then, they shall eat the fruit of their own way, and with their own devices be glutted.

32.verse: For the straying of the naive kills them, the smugness of fools destroys them.

33.verse: But whoever obeys me dwells in security, in peace, without fear of harm.”

1.verse: Chapter 2 The Blessings of Wisdom - My son, if you receive my words and treasure my commands,

2.verse: Turning your ear to wisdom, inclining your heart to understanding;

3.verse: Yes, if you call for intelligence, and to understanding raise your voice;

4.verse: If you seek her like silver, and like hidden treasures search her out,

5.verse: Then will you understand the fear of the LORD; the knowledge of God you will find;

6.verse: For the LORD gives wisdom, from his mouth come knowledge and understanding;

7.verse: He has success in store for the upright, is the shield of those who walk honestly,

8.verse: Guarding the paths of justice, protecting the way of his faithful ones,

9.verse: Then you will understand what is right and just, what is fair, every good path;

10.verse: For wisdom will enter your heart, knowledge will be at home in your soul,

11.verse: Discretion will watch over you, understanding will guard you;

12.verse: Saving you from the way of the wicked, from those whose speech is perverse.

13.verse: From those who have left the straight paths to walk in the ways of darkness,

14.verse: Who delight in doing evil and celebrate perversity;

15.verse: Whose ways are crooked, whose paths are devious;

16.verse: Saving you from a stranger, from a foreign woman with her smooth words,

17.verse: One who forsakes the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God;

18.verse: For her path sinks down to death, and her footsteps lead to the shades.

19.verse: None who enter there come back, or gain the paths of life.

20.verse: Thus you may walk in the way of the good, and keep to the paths of the just.

21.verse: For the upright will dwell in the land, people of integrity will remain in it;

22.verse: But the wicked will be cut off from the land, the faithless will be rooted out of it.

1.verse: Chapter 3 Confidence in God Leads to Prosperity - My son, do not forget my teaching, take to heart my commands;

2.verse: For many days, and years of life, and peace, will they bring you.

3.verse: Do not let love and fidelity forsake you; bind them around your neck; write them on the tablet of your heart.

4.verse: Then will you win favor and esteem before God and human beings.

5.verse: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, on your own intelligence do not rely;

6.verse: In all your ways be mindful of him, and he will make straight your paths.

7.verse: Do not be wise in your own eyes, fear the LORD and turn away from evil;

8.verse: This will mean health for your flesh and vigor for your bones.

9.verse: Honor the LORD with your wealth, with first fruits of all your produce;

10.verse: Then will your barns be filled with plenty, with new wine your vats will overflow.

11.verse: The discipline of the LORD, my son, do not spurn; do not disdain his reproof;

12.verse: For whom the LORD loves he reproves, as a father, the son he favors.

13.verse: The Benefits of Finding Wisdom - Happy the one who finds wisdom, the one who gains understanding!

14.verse: Her profit is better than profit in silver, and better than gold is her revenue;

15.verse: She is more precious than corals, and no treasure of yours can compare with her.

16.verse: Long life is in her right hand, in her left are riches and honor;

17.verse: Her ways are pleasant ways, and all her paths are peace;

18.verse: She is a tree of life to those who grasp her, and those who hold her fast are happy.

19.verse: The LORD by wisdom founded the earth, established the heavens by understanding;

20.verse: By his knowledge the depths are split, and the clouds drop down dew.

21.verse: Justice Toward One’s Neighbor Brings Blessing - My son, do not let these slip from your sight: hold to deliberation and planning;

22.verse: So will they be life to your soul, and an adornment for your neck.

23.verse: Then you may go your way securely; your foot will never stumble;

24.verse: When you lie down, you will not be afraid, when you rest, your sleep will be sweet.

25.verse: Do not be afraid of sudden terror, of the ruin of the wicked when it comes;

26.verse: For the LORD will be your confidence, and will keep your foot from the snare.

27.verse: Do not withhold any goods from the owner when it is in your power to act.

28.verse: Say not to your neighbor, “Go, come back tomorrow, and I will give it to you,” when all the while you have it.

29.verse: Do not plot evil against your neighbors, when they live at peace with you.

30.verse: Do not contend with someone without cause, with one who has done you no harm.

31.verse: Do not envy the violent and choose none of their ways:

32.verse: To the LORD the devious are an abomination, but the upright are close to him.

33.verse: The curse of the LORD is on the house of the wicked, but the dwelling of the just he blesses;

34.verse: Those who scoff, he scoffs at, but the lowly he favors.

35.verse: The wise will possess glory, but fools will bear shame.

1.verse: Chapter 4 The Teacher as Model Disciple - Hear, O children, a father’s instruction, be attentive, that you may gain understanding!

2.verse: Yes, excellent advice I give you; my teaching do not forsake.

3.verse: When I was my father’s child, tender, the darling of my mother,

4.verse: He taught me and said to me: “Let your heart hold fast my words: keep my commands, and live!

5.verse: Get wisdom, get understanding! Do not forget or turn aside from the words of my mouth.

6.verse: Do not forsake her, and she will preserve you; love her, and she will safeguard you;

7.verse: The beginning of wisdom is: get wisdom; whatever else you get, get understanding.

8.verse: Extol her, and she will exalt you; she will bring you honors if you embrace her;

9.verse: She will put on your head a graceful diadem; a glorious crown will she bestow on you.”

10.verse: The Two Ways - Hear, my son, and receive my words, and the years of your life shall be many.

11.verse: On the way of wisdom I direct you, I lead you on straight paths.

12.verse: When you walk, your step will not be impeded, and should you run, you will not stumble.

13.verse: Hold fast to instruction, never let it go; keep it, for it is your life.

14.verse: The path of the wicked do not enter, nor walk in the way of the evil;

15.verse: Shun it, do not cross it, turn aside from it, pass on.

16.verse: For they cannot rest unless they have done evil; if they do not trip anyone they lose sleep.

17.verse: For they eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.

18.verse: But the path of the just is like shining light, that grows in brilliance till perfect day.

19.verse: The way of the wicked is like darkness; they do not know on what they stumble.

20.verse: With Your Whole Being Heed My Words and Live - My son, to my words be attentive, to my sayings incline your ear;

21.verse: Let them not slip from your sight, keep them within your heart;

22.verse: For they are life to those who find them, bringing health to one’s whole being.

23.verse: With all vigilance guard your heart, for in it are the sources of life.

24.verse: Dishonest mouth put away from you, deceitful lips put far from you.

25.verse: Let your eyes look straight ahead and your gaze be focused forward.

26.verse: Survey the path for your feet, and all your ways will be sure.

27.verse: Turn neither to right nor to left, keep your foot far from evil.

1.verse: Chapter 5 Warning Against Adultery - My son, to my wisdom be attentive, to understanding incline your ear,

2.verse: That you may act discreetly, and your lips guard what you know.

3.verse: Indeed, the lips of the stranger drip honey, and her mouth is smoother than oil;

4.verse: But in the end she is as bitter as wormwood, as sharp as a two-edged sword.

5.verse: Her feet go down to death, her steps reach Sheol;

6.verse: Her paths ramble, you know not where, lest you see before you the road to life.

7.verse: So now, children, listen to me, do not stray from the words of my mouth.

8.verse: Keep your way far from her, do not go near the door of her house,

9.verse: Lest you give your honor to others, and your years to a merciless one;

10.verse: Lest outsiders take their fill of your wealth, and your hard-won earnings go to another’s house;

11.verse: And you groan in the end, when your flesh and your body are consumed;

12.verse: And you say, “Oh, why did I hate instruction, and my heart spurn reproof!

13.verse: Why did I not listen to the voice of my teachers, incline my ear to my instructors!

14.verse: I am all but ruined, in the midst of the public assembly!”

15.verse: Drink water from your own cistern, running water from your own well.

16.verse: Should your water sources be dispersed abroad, streams of water in the streets?

17.verse: Let them be yours alone, not shared with outsiders;

18.verse: Let your fountain be blessed and have joy of the wife of your youth,

19.verse: your lovely hind, your graceful doe. Of whose love you will ever have your fill, and by her ardor always be intoxicated.

20.verse: Why then, my son, should you be intoxicated with a stranger, and embrace another woman?

21.verse: Indeed, the ways of each person are plain to the LORD’s sight; all their paths he surveys;

22.verse: By their own iniquities the wicked will be caught, in the meshes of their own sin they will be held fast;

23.verse: They will die from lack of discipline, lost because of their great folly.

1.verse: Chapter 6 Miscellaneous Proverbs - Against Going Surety for One’s Neighbor My son, if you have become surety to your neighbor, given your hand in pledge to another,

2.verse: You have been snared by the utterance of your lips, caught by the words of your mouth;

3.verse: So do this, my son, to free yourself, since you have fallen into your neighbor’s power: Go, hurry, rouse your neighbor!

4.verse: Give no sleep to your eyes, nor slumber to your eyelids;

5.verse: Free yourself like a gazelle from the hunter, or like a bird from the hand of the fowler.

6.verse: The Ant and the Sluggard at Harvest Go to the ant, O sluggard, study her ways and learn wisdom;

7.verse: For though she has no chief, no commander or ruler,

8.verse: She procures her food in the summer, stores up her provisions in the harvest.

9.verse: How long, O sluggard, will you lie there? when will you rise from your sleep?

10.verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest—

11.verse: Then poverty will come upon you like a robber, and want like a brigand.

12.verse: The Scoundrel Scoundrels, villains, are they who deal in crooked talk.

13.verse: Shifty of eye, feet ever moving, pointing with fingers,

14.verse: They have perversity in their hearts, always plotting evil, sowing discord.

15.verse: Therefore their doom comes suddenly; in an instant they are crushed beyond cure.

16.verse: What the Lord Rejects There are six things the LORD hates, yes, seven are an abomination to him;

17.verse: Haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,

18.verse: A heart that plots wicked schemes, feet that are quick to run to evil,

19.verse: The false witness who utters lies, and the one who sows discord among kindred.

20.verse: Warning Against Adultery Observe, my son, your father’s command, and do not reject your mother’s teaching;

21.verse: Keep them fastened over your heart always, tie them around your neck.

22.verse: When you lie down they will watch over you, when you wake, they will share your concerns; wherever you turn, they will guide you.

23.verse: For the command is a lamp, and the teaching a light, and a way to life are the reproofs that discipline,

24.verse: Keeping you from another’s wife, from the smooth tongue of the foreign woman.

25.verse: Do not lust in your heart after her beauty, do not let her captivate you with her glance!

26.verse: For the price of a harlot may be scarcely a loaf of bread, But a married woman is a trap for your precious life.

27.verse: Can a man take embers into his bosom, and his garments not be burned?

28.verse: Or can a man walk on live coals, and his feet not be scorched?

29.verse: So with him who sleeps with another’s wife— none who touches her shall go unpunished.

30.verse: Thieves are not despised if out of hunger they steal to satisfy their appetite.

31.verse: Yet if caught they must pay back sevenfold, yield up all the wealth of their house.

32.verse: But those who commit adultery have no sense; those who do it destroy themselves.

33.verse: They will be beaten and disgraced, and their shame will not be wiped away;

34.verse: For passion enrages the husband, he will have no pity on the day of vengeance;

35.verse: He will not consider any restitution, nor be satisfied by your many bribes.

1.verse: Chapter 7 The Seduction - My son, keep my words, and treasure my commands.

2.verse: Keep my commands and live, and my teaching as the apple of your eye;

3.verse: Bind them on your fingers, write them on the tablet of your heart.

4.verse: Say to Wisdom, “You are my sister!” Call Understanding, “Friend!”

5.verse: That they may keep you from a stranger, from the foreign woman with her smooth words.

6.verse: For at the window of my house, through my lattice I looked out

7.verse: And I saw among the naive, I observed among the young men, a youth with no sense,

8.verse: Crossing the street near the corner, then walking toward her house,

9.verse: In the twilight, at dusk of day, in the very dark of night.

10.verse: Then the woman comes to meet him, dressed like a harlot, with secret designs.

11.verse: She is raucous and unruly, her feet cannot stay at home;

12.verse: Now she is in the streets, now in the open squares, lurking in ambush at every corner.

13.verse: Then she grabs him, kisses him, and with an impudent look says to him:

14.verse: “I owed peace offerings, and today I have fulfilled my vows;

15.verse: So I came out to meet you, to look for you, and I have found you!

16.verse: With coverlets I have spread my couch, with brocaded cloths of Egyptian linen;

17.verse: I have sprinkled my bed with myrrh, with aloes, and with cinnamon.

18.verse: Come, let us drink our fill of love, until morning, let us feast on love!

19.verse: For my husband is not at home, he has gone on a long journey;

20.verse: A bag of money he took with him, he will not return home till the full moon.”

21.verse: She wins him over by repeated urging, with her smooth lips she leads him astray.

22.verse: He follows her impulsively, like an ox that goes to slaughter; Like a stag that bounds toward the net,

23.verse: till an arrow pierces its liver; Like a bird that rushes into a snare, unaware that his life is at stake.

24.verse: So now, children, listen to me, be attentive to the words of my mouth!

25.verse: Do not let your heart turn to her ways, do not go astray in her paths;

26.verse: For many are those she has struck down dead, numerous, those she has slain.

27.verse: Her house is a highway to Sheol, leading down into the chambers of death.

1.verse: Chapter 8 The Discourse of Wisdom - Does not Wisdom call, and Understanding raise her voice?

2.verse: On the top of the heights along the road, at the crossroads she takes her stand;

3.verse: By the gates at the approaches of the city, in the entryways she cries aloud:

4.verse: “To you, O people, I call; my appeal is to you mortals.

5.verse: You naive ones, gain prudence, you fools, gain sense.

6.verse: Listen! for noble things I speak; my lips proclaim honest words.

7.verse: Indeed, my mouth utters truth, and my lips abhor wickedness.

8.verse: All the words of my mouth are sincere, none of them wily or crooked;

9.verse: All of them are straightforward to the intelligent, and right to those who attain knowledge.

10.verse: Take my instruction instead of silver, and knowledge rather than choice gold.

11.verse: [For Wisdom is better than corals, and no treasures can compare with her.]

12.verse: I, Wisdom, dwell with prudence, and useful knowledge I have.

13.verse: [The fear of the LORD is hatred of evil;] Pride, arrogance, the evil way, and the perverse mouth I hate.

14.verse: Mine are counsel and advice; Mine is strength; I am understanding.

15.verse: By me kings reign, and rulers enact justice;

16.verse: By me princes govern, and nobles, all the judges of the earth.

17.verse: Those who love me I also love, and those who seek me find me.

18.verse: With me are riches and honor, wealth that endures, and righteousness.

19.verse: My fruit is better than gold, even pure gold, and my yield than choice silver.

20.verse: On the way of righteousness I walk, along the paths of justice,

21.verse: Granting wealth to those who love me, and filling their treasuries.

22.verse: “The LORD begot me, the beginning of his works, the forerunner of his deeds of long ago;

23.verse: From of old I was formed, at the first, before the earth.

24.verse: When there were no deeps I was brought forth, when there were no fountains or springs of water;

25.verse: Before the mountains were settled into place, before the hills, I was brought forth;

26.verse: When the earth and the fields were not yet made, nor the first clods of the world.

27.verse: When he established the heavens, there was I, when he marked out the vault over the face of the deep;

28.verse: When he made firm the skies above, when he fixed fast the springs of the deep;

29.verse: When he set for the sea its limit, so that the waters should not transgress his command; When he fixed the foundations of earth,

30.verse: then was I beside him as artisan; I was his delight day by day, playing before him all the while,

31.verse: Playing over the whole of his earth, having my delight with human beings.

32.verse: Now, children, listen to me; happy are they who keep my ways.

33.verse: Listen to instruction and grow wise, do not reject it!

34.verse: Happy the one who listens to me, attending daily at my gates, keeping watch at my doorposts;

35.verse: For whoever finds me finds life, and wins favor from the LORD;

36.verse: But those who pass me by do violence to themselves; all who hate me love death.”

1.verse: Chapter 9 The Two Women Invite Passersby to Their Banquets - Woman Wisdom Issues Her Invitation Wisdom has built her house, she has set up her seven columns;

2.verse: She has prepared her meat, mixed her wine, yes, she has spread her table.

3.verse: She has sent out her maidservants; she calls from the heights out over the city:

4.verse: “Let whoever is naive turn in here; to any who lack sense I say,

5.verse: Come, eat of my food, and drink of the wine I have mixed!

6.verse: Forsake foolishness that you may live; advance in the way of understanding.”

7.verse: Miscellaneous Aphorisms Whoever corrects the arrogant earns insults; and whoever reproves the wicked incurs opprobrium.

8.verse: Do not reprove the arrogant, lest they hate you; reprove the wise, and they will love you.

9.verse: Instruct the wise, and they become still wiser; teach the just, and they advance in learning.

10.verse: The beginning of wisdom is fear of the LORD, and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.

11.verse: For by me your days will be multiplied and the years of your life increased.

12.verse: If you are wise, wisdom is to your advantage; if you are arrogant, you alone shall bear it.

13.verse: Woman Folly Issues Her Invitation Woman Folly is raucous, utterly foolish; she knows nothing.

14.verse: She sits at the door of her house upon a seat on the city heights,

15.verse: Calling to passersby as they go on their way straight ahead:

16.verse: “Let those who are naive turn in here, to those who lack sense I say,

17.verse: Stolen water is sweet, and bread taken secretly is pleasing!”

18.verse: Little do they know that the shades are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol!

1.verse: III. First Solomonic Collection of Sayings Chapter 10 - The Proverbs of Solomon: A wise son gives his father joy, but a foolish son is a grief to his mother.

2.verse: Ill-gotten treasures profit nothing, but justice saves from death.

3.verse: The LORD does not let the just go hungry, but the craving of the wicked he thwarts.

4.verse: The slack hand impoverishes, but the busy hand brings riches.

5.verse: A son who gathers in summer is a credit; a son who slumbers during harvest, a disgrace.

6.verse: Blessings are for the head of the just; but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

7.verse: The memory of the just serves as blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot.

8.verse: A wise heart accepts commands, but a babbling fool will be overthrown.

9.verse: Whoever walks honestly walks securely, but one whose ways are crooked will fare badly.

10.verse: One who winks at a fault causes trouble, but one who frankly reproves promotes peace.

11.verse: The mouth of the just is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

12.verse: Hatred stirs up disputes, but love covers all offenses.

13.verse: On the lips of the intelligent is found wisdom, but a rod for the back of one without sense.

14.verse: The wise store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool is imminent ruin.

15.verse: The wealth of the rich is their strong city; the ruin of the poor is their poverty.

16.verse: The labor of the just leads to life, the gains of the wicked, to futility.

17.verse: Whoever follows instruction is in the path to life, but whoever disregards reproof goes astray.

18.verse: Whoever conceals hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool.

19.verse: Where words are many, sin is not wanting; but those who restrain their lips do well.

20.verse: Choice silver is the tongue of the just; the heart of the wicked is of little worth.

21.verse: The lips of the just nourish many, but fools die for want of sense.

22.verse: It is the LORD’s blessing that brings wealth, and no effort can substitute for it.

23.verse: Crime is the entertainment of the fool; but wisdom is for the person of understanding.

24.verse: What the wicked fear will befall them, but the desire of the just will be granted.

25.verse: When the tempest passes, the wicked are no more; but the just are established forever.

26.verse: As vinegar to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, are sluggards to those who send them.

27.verse: Fear of the LORD prolongs life, but the years of the wicked are cut short.

28.verse: The hope of the just brings joy, but the expectation of the wicked perishes.

29.verse: The LORD is a stronghold to those who walk honestly, downfall for evildoers.

30.verse: The just will never be disturbed, but the wicked will not abide in the land.

31.verse: The mouth of the just yields wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut off.

32.verse: The lips of the just know favor, but the mouth of the wicked, perversion.

1.verse: Chapter 11 - False scales are an abomination to the LORD, but an honest weight, his delight.

2.verse: When pride comes, disgrace comes; but with the humble is wisdom.

3.verse: The honesty of the upright guides them; the faithless are ruined by their duplicity.

4.verse: Wealth is useless on a day of wrath, but justice saves from death.

5.verse: The justice of the honest makes their way straight, but by their wickedness the wicked fall.

6.verse: The justice of the upright saves them, but the faithless are caught in their own intrigue.

7.verse: When a person dies, hope is destroyed; expectation pinned on wealth is destroyed.

8.verse: The just are rescued from a tight spot, but the wicked fall into it instead.

9.verse: By a word the impious ruin their neighbors, but through their knowledge the just are rescued.

10.verse: When the just prosper, the city rejoices; when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.

11.verse: Through the blessing of the upright the city is exalted, but through the mouth of the wicked it is overthrown.

12.verse: Whoever reviles a neighbor lacks sense, but the intelligent keep silent.

13.verse: One who slanders reveals secrets, but a trustworthy person keeps a confidence.

14.verse: For lack of guidance a people falls; security lies in many counselors.

15.verse: Harm will come to anyone going surety for another, but whoever hates giving pledges is secure.

16.verse: A gracious woman gains esteem, and ruthless men gain wealth.

17.verse: Kindly people benefit themselves, but the merciless harm themselves.

18.verse: The wicked make empty profits, but those who sow justice have a sure reward.

19.verse: Justice leads toward life, but pursuit of evil, toward death.

20.verse: The crooked in heart are an abomination to the LORD, but those who walk blamelessly are his delight.

21.verse: Be assured, the wicked shall not go unpunished, but the offspring of the just shall escape.

22.verse: Like a golden ring in a swine’s snout is a beautiful woman without judgment.

23.verse: The desire of the just ends only in good; the expectation of the wicked is wrath.

24.verse: One person is lavish yet grows still richer; another is too sparing, yet is the poorer.

25.verse: Whoever confers benefits will be amply enriched, and whoever refreshes others will be refreshed.

26.verse: Whoever hoards grain, the people curse, but blessings are on the head of one who distributes it!

27.verse: Those who seek the good seek favor, but those who pursue evil will have evil come upon them.

28.verse: Those who trust in their riches will fall, but like green leaves the just will flourish.

29.verse: Those who trouble their household inherit the wind, and fools become slaves to the wise of heart.

30.verse: The fruit of justice is a tree of life, and one who takes lives is a sage.

31.verse: If the just are recompensed on the earth, how much more the wicked and the sinner!

1.verse: Chapter 12 - Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but whoever hates reproof is stupid.

2.verse: A good person wins favor from the LORD, but the schemer he condemns.

3.verse: No one is made secure by wickedness, but the root of the just will never be disturbed.

4.verse: A woman of worth is the crown of her husband, but a disgraceful one is like rot in his bones.

5.verse: The plans of the just are right; the designs of the wicked are deceit.

6.verse: The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush, but the speech of the upright saves them.

7.verse: Overthrow the wicked and they are no more, but the house of the just stands firm.

8.verse: For their good sense people are praised, but the perverse of heart are despised.

9.verse: Better to be slighted and have a servant than put on airs and lack bread.

10.verse: The just take care of their livestock, but the compassion of the wicked is cruel.

11.verse: Those who till their own land have food in plenty, but those who engage in idle pursuits lack sense.

12.verse: A wicked person desires the catch of evil people, but the root of the righteous will bear fruit.

13.verse: By the sin of their lips the wicked are ensnared, but the just escape from a tight spot.

14.verse: From the fruit of their mouths people have their fill of good, and the works of their hands come back upon them.

15.verse: The way of fools is right in their own eyes, but those who listen to advice are the wise.

16.verse: Fools immediately show their anger, but the shrewd conceal contempt.

17.verse: Whoever speaks honestly testifies truly, but the deceitful make lying witnesses.

18.verse: The babble of some people is like sword thrusts, but the tongue of the wise is healing.

19.verse: Truthful lips endure forever, the lying tongue, for only a moment.

20.verse: Deceit is in the heart of those who plot evil, but those who counsel peace have joy.

21.verse: No harm befalls the just, but the wicked are overwhelmed with misfortune.

22.verse: Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, but those who are truthful, his delight.

23.verse: The shrewd conceal knowledge, but the hearts of fools proclaim folly.

24.verse: The diligent hand will govern, but sloth makes for forced labor.

25.verse: Worry weighs down the heart, but a kind word gives it joy.

26.verse: The just act as guides to their neighbors, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.

27.verse: Sloth does not catch its prey, but the wealth of the diligent is splendid.

28.verse: In the path of justice is life, but the way of abomination leads to death.

1.verse: Chapter 13 - A wise son loves correction, but the scoffer heeds no rebuke.

2.verse: From the fruit of the mouth one enjoys good things, but from the throat of the treacherous comes violence.

3.verse: Those who guard their mouths preserve themselves; those who open wide their lips bring ruin.

4.verse: The appetite of the sluggard craves but has nothing, but the appetite of the diligent is amply satisfied.

5.verse: The just hate deceitful words, but the wicked are odious and disgraceful.

6.verse: Justice guards one who walks honestly, but sin leads the wicked astray.

7.verse: One acts rich but has nothing; another acts poor but has great wealth.

8.verse: People’s riches serve as ransom for their lives, but the poor do not even hear a threat.

9.verse: The light of the just gives joy, but the lamp of the wicked goes out.

10.verse: The stupid sow discord by their insolence, but wisdom is with those who take counsel.

11.verse: Wealth won quickly dwindles away, but gathered little by little, it grows.

12.verse: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a wish fulfilled is a tree of life.

13.verse: Whoever despises the word must pay for it, but whoever reveres the command will be rewarded.

14.verse: The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, turning one from the snares of death.

15.verse: Good sense brings favor, but the way of the faithless is their ruin.

16.verse: The shrewd always act prudently but the foolish parade folly.

17.verse: A wicked messenger brings on disaster, but a trustworthy envoy is a healing remedy.

18.verse: Poverty and shame befall those who let go of discipline, but those who hold on to reproof receive honor.

19.verse: Desire fulfilled delights the soul, but turning from evil is an abomination to fools.

20.verse: Walk with the wise and you become wise, but the companion of fools fares badly.

21.verse: Misfortune pursues sinners, but the just shall be recompensed with good.

22.verse: The good leave an inheritance to their children’s children, but the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the just.

23.verse: The tillage of the poor yields abundant food, but possessions are swept away for lack of justice.

24.verse: Whoever spares the rod hates the child, but whoever loves will apply discipline.

25.verse: When the just eat, their hunger is appeased; but the belly of the wicked suffers want.

1.verse: Chapter 14 - Wisdom builds her house, but Folly tears hers down with her own hands.

2.verse: Those who walk uprightly fear the LORD, but those who are devious in their ways spurn him.

3.verse: In the mouth of the fool is a rod for pride, but the lips of the wise preserve them.

4.verse: Where there are no oxen, the crib is clean; but abundant crops come through the strength of the bull.

5.verse: A trustworthy witness does not lie, but one who spouts lies makes a lying witness.

6.verse: The scoffer seeks wisdom in vain, but knowledge is easy for the intelligent.

7.verse: Go from the face of the fool; you get no knowledge from such lips.

8.verse: The wisdom of the shrewd enlightens their way, but the folly of fools is deceit.

9.verse: The wicked scorn a guilt offering, but the upright find acceptance.

10.verse: The heart knows its own bitterness, and its joy no stranger shares.

11.verse: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will flourish.

12.verse: Sometimes a way seems right, but the end of it leads to death!

13.verse: Even in laughter the heart may be sad, and the end of joy may be sorrow.

14.verse: From their own ways turncoats are sated, from their own actions, the loyal.

15.verse: The naive believe everything, but the shrewd watch their steps.

16.verse: The wise person is cautious and turns from evil; the fool is reckless and gets embroiled.

17.verse: The quick-tempered make fools of themselves, and schemers are hated.

18.verse: The simple have folly as an adornment, but the shrewd wear knowledge as a crown.

19.verse: The malicious bow down before the good, and the wicked, at the gates of the just.

20.verse: Even by their neighbors the poor are despised, but a rich person’s friends are many.

21.verse: Whoever despises the hungry comes up short, but happy the one who is kind to the poor!

22.verse: Do not those who plan evil go astray? But those who plan good win steadfast loyalty.

23.verse: In all labor there is profit, but mere talk tends only to loss.

24.verse: The crown of the wise is wealth; the diadem of fools is folly.

25.verse: The truthful witness saves lives, but whoever utters lies is a betrayer.

26.verse: The fear of the LORD is a strong defense, a refuge even for one’s children.

27.verse: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, turning one from the snares of death.

28.verse: A multitude of subjects is the glory of the king; but if his people are few, a prince is ruined.

29.verse: Long-suffering results in great wisdom; a short temper raises folly high.

30.verse: A tranquil mind gives life to the body, but jealousy rots the bones.

31.verse: Those who oppress the poor revile their Maker, but those who are kind to the needy honor him.

32.verse: The wicked are overthrown by their wickedness, but the just find a refuge in their integrity.

33.verse: Wisdom can remain silent in the discerning heart, but among fools she must make herself known.

34.verse: Justice exalts a nation, but sin is a people’s disgrace.

35.verse: The king favors the skillful servant, but the shameless one incurs his wrath.

1.verse: Chapter 15 - A mild answer turns back wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.

2.verse: The tongue of the wise pours out knowledge, but the mouth of fools spews folly.

3.verse: The eyes of the LORD are in every place, keeping watch on the evil and the good.

4.verse: A soothing tongue is a tree of life, but a perverse one breaks the spirit.

5.verse: The fool spurns a father’s instruction, but whoever heeds reproof is prudent.

6.verse: In the house of the just there are ample resources, but the harvest of the wicked is in peril.

7.verse: The lips of the wise spread knowledge, but the heart of fools is not steadfast.

8.verse: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is his delight.

9.verse: The way of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD, but he loves one who pursues justice.

10.verse: Discipline seems bad to those going astray; one who hates reproof will die.

11.verse: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD; how much more the hearts of mortals!

12.verse: Scoffers do not love reproof; to the wise they will not go.

13.verse: A glad heart lights up the face, but an anguished heart breaks the spirit.

14.verse: The discerning heart seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on folly.

15.verse: All the days of the poor are evil, but a good heart is a continual feast.

16.verse: Better a little with fear of the LORD than a great fortune with anxiety.

17.verse: Better a dish of herbs where love is than a fatted ox and hatred with it.

18.verse: The ill-tempered stir up strife, but the patient settle disputes.

19.verse: The way of the sluggard is like a thorn hedge, but the path of the diligent is a highway.

20.verse: A wise son gives his father joy, but a fool despises his mother.

21.verse: Folly is joy to the senseless, but the person of understanding goes the straight way.

22.verse: Plans fail when there is no counsel, but they succeed when advisers are many.

23.verse: One has joy from an apt response; a word in season, how good it is!

24.verse: The path of life leads upward for the prudent, turning them from Sheol below.

25.verse: The LORD pulls down the house of the proud, but preserves intact the widow’s landmark.

26.verse: The schemes of the wicked are an abomination to the LORD, but gracious words are pure.

27.verse: The greedy tear down their own house, but those who hate bribes will live.

28.verse: The heart of the just ponders a response, but the mouth of the wicked spews evil.

29.verse: The LORD is far from the wicked, but hears the prayer of the just.

30.verse: A cheerful glance brings joy to the heart; good news invigorates the bones.

31.verse: The ear that listens to salutary reproof is at home among the wise.

32.verse: Those who disregard discipline hate themselves, but those who heed reproof acquire understanding.

33.verse: The fear of the LORD is training for wisdom, and humility goes before honors.

1.verse: Chapter 16 - Plans are made in human hearts, but from the LORD comes the tongue’s response.

2.verse: All one’s ways are pure in one’s own eyes, but the measurer of motives is the LORD.

3.verse: Entrust your works to the LORD, and your plans will succeed.

4.verse: The LORD has made everything for a purpose, even the wicked for the evil day.

5.verse: Every proud heart is an abomination to the LORD; be assured that none will go unpunished.

6.verse: By steadfast loyalty guilt is expiated, and by the fear of the LORD evil is avoided.

7.verse: When the LORD is pleased with someone’s ways, he makes even enemies be at peace with them.

8.verse: Better a little with justice, than a large income with injustice.

9.verse: The human heart plans the way, but the LORD directs the steps.

10.verse: An oracle is upon the king’s lips, no judgment of his mouth is false.

11.verse: Balance and scales belong to the LORD; every weight in the sack is his concern.

12.verse: Wrongdoing is an abomination to kings, for by justice the throne endures.

13.verse: The king takes delight in honest lips, and whoever speaks what is right he loves.

14.verse: The king’s wrath is a messenger of death, but a wise person can pacify it.

15.verse: A king’s smile means life, and his favor is like a rain cloud in spring.

16.verse: How much better to get wisdom than gold! To get understanding is preferable to silver.

17.verse: The path of the upright leads away from misfortune; those who attend to their way guard their lives.

18.verse: Pride goes before disaster, and a haughty spirit before a fall.

19.verse: It is better to be humble with the poor than to share plunder with the proud.

20.verse: Whoever ponders a matter will be successful; happy the one who trusts in the LORD!

21.verse: The wise of heart is esteemed for discernment, and pleasing speech gains a reputation for learning.

22.verse: Good sense is a fountain of life to those who have it, but folly is the training of fools.

23.verse: The heart of the wise makes for eloquent speech, and increases the learning on their lips.

24.verse: Pleasing words are a honeycomb, sweet to the taste and invigorating to the bones.

25.verse: Sometimes a way seems right, but the end of it leads to death!

26.verse: The appetite of workers works for them, for their mouths urge them on.

27.verse: Scoundrels are a furnace of evil, and their lips are like a scorching fire.

28.verse: Perverse speech sows discord, and talebearing separates bosom friends.

29.verse: The violent deceive their neighbors, and lead them into a way that is not good.

30.verse: Whoever winks an eye plans perversity; whoever purses the lips does evil.

31.verse: Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is gained by a life that is just.

32.verse: The patient are better than warriors, and those who rule their temper, better than the conqueror of a city.

33.verse: Into the bag the lot is cast, but from the LORD comes every decision.

1.verse: Chapter 17 - Better a dry crust with quiet than a house full of feasting with strife.

2.verse: A wise servant will rule over an unworthy son, and will share the inheritance of the children.

3.verse: The crucible for silver, and the furnace for gold, but the tester of hearts is the LORD.

4.verse: The evildoer gives heed to wicked lips, the liar, to a mischievous tongue.

5.verse: Whoever mocks the poor reviles their Maker; whoever rejoices in their misfortune will not go unpunished.

6.verse: Children’s children are the crown of the elderly, and the glory of children is their parentage.

7.verse: Fine words ill fit a fool; how much more lying lips, a noble!

8.verse: A bribe seems a charm to its user; at every turn it brings success.

9.verse: Whoever overlooks an offense fosters friendship, but whoever gossips about it separates friends.

10.verse: A single reprimand does more for a discerning person than a hundred lashes for a fool.

11.verse: The wicked pursue only rebellion, and a merciless messenger is sent against them.

12.verse: Face a bear robbed of her cubs, but never fools in their folly!

13.verse: If you return evil for good, evil will not depart from your house.

14.verse: The start of strife is like the opening of a dam; check a quarrel before it bursts forth!

15.verse: Whoever acquits the wicked, whoever condemns the just— both are an abomination to the LORD.

16.verse: Of what use is money in the hands of fools when they have no heart to acquire wisdom?

17.verse: A friend is a friend at all times, and a brother is born for the time of adversity.

18.verse: Those without sense give their hands in pledge, becoming surety for their neighbors.

19.verse: Those who love an offense love a fight; those who build their gate high court disaster.

20.verse: The perverse in heart come to no good, and the double-tongued fall into trouble.

21.verse: Whoever conceives a fool has grief; the father of a numskull has no joy.

22.verse: A joyful heart is the health of the body, but a depressed spirit dries up the bones.

23.verse: A guilty person takes out a bribe from the pocket, thus perverting the course of justice.

24.verse: On the countenance of a discerning person is wisdom, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.

25.verse: A foolish son is vexation to his father, and bitter sorrow to her who bore him.

26.verse: It is wrong to fine an innocent person, but beyond reason to scourge nobles.

27.verse: Those who spare their words are truly knowledgeable, and those who are discreet are intelligent.

28.verse: Even fools, keeping silent, are considered wise; if they keep their lips closed, intelligent.

1.verse: Chapter 18 - One who is alienated seeks a pretext, with all persistence picks a quarrel.

2.verse: Fools take no delight in understanding, but only in displaying what they think.

3.verse: With wickedness comes contempt, and with disgrace, scorn.

4.verse: The words of one’s mouth are deep waters, the spring of wisdom, a running brook.

5.verse: It is not good to favor the guilty, nor to reject the claim of the just.

6.verse: The lips of fools walk into a fight, and their mouths are asking for a beating.

7.verse: The mouths of fools are their ruin; their lips are a deadly snare.

8.verse: The words of a talebearer are like dainty morsels: they sink into one’s inmost being.

9.verse: Those slack in their work are kin to the destroyer.

10.verse: The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the just run to it and are safe.

11.verse: The wealth of the rich is their strong city; they fancy it a high wall.

12.verse: Before disaster the heart is haughty, but before honor is humility.

13.verse: Whoever answers before listening, theirs is folly and shame.

14.verse: One’s spirit supports one when ill, but a broken spirit who can bear?

15.verse: The heart of the intelligent acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.

16.verse: Gifts clear the way for people, winning access to the great.

17.verse: Those who plead the case first seem to be in the right; then the opponent comes and cross-examines them.

18.verse: The lot puts an end to disputes, and decides a controversy between the mighty.

19.verse: A brother offended is more unyielding than a stronghold; such strife is more daunting than castle gates.

20.verse: With the fruit of one’s mouth one’s belly is filled, with the produce of one’s lips one is sated.

21.verse: Death and life are in the power of the tongue; those who choose one shall eat its fruit.

22.verse: To find a wife is to find happiness, a favor granted by the LORD.

23.verse: The poor implore, but the rich answer harshly.

24.verse: There are friends who bring ruin, but there are true friends more loyal than a brother.

1.verse: Chapter 19 - Better to be poor and walk in integrity than rich and crooked in one’s ways.

2.verse: Desire without knowledge is not good; and whoever acts hastily, blunders.

3.verse: Their own folly leads people astray; in their hearts they rage against the LORD.

4.verse: Wealth adds many friends, but the poor are left friendless.

5.verse: The false witness will not go unpunished, and whoever utters lies will not escape.

6.verse: Many curry favor with a noble; everybody is a friend of a gift giver.

7.verse: All the kin of the poor despise them; how much more do their friends shun them!

8.verse: Those who gain sense truly love themselves; those who preserve understanding will find success.

9.verse: The false witness will not go unpunished, and whoever utters lies will perish.

10.verse: Luxury is not befitting a fool; much less should a slave rule over princes.

11.verse: It is good sense to be slow to anger, and an honor to overlook an offense.

12.verse: The king’s wrath is like the roar of a lion, but his favor, like dew on the grass.

13.verse: The foolish son is ruin to his father, and a quarrelsome wife is water constantly dripping.

14.verse: Home and possessions are an inheritance from parents, but a prudent wife is from the LORD.

15.verse: Laziness brings on deep sleep, and the sluggard goes hungry.

16.verse: Those who keep commands keep their lives, but those who despise these ways will die.

17.verse: Whoever cares for the poor lends to the LORD, who will pay back the sum in full.

18.verse: Discipline your son, for there is hope; but do not be intent on his death.

19.verse: A wrathful person bears the penalty; after one rescue, you will have it to do again.

20.verse: Listen to counsel and receive instruction, that you may eventually become wise.

21.verse: Many are the plans of the human heart, but it is the decision of the LORD that endures.

22.verse: What is desired of a person is fidelity; rather be poor than a liar.

23.verse: The fear of the LORD leads to life; one eats and sleeps free from any harm.

24.verse: The sluggard buries a hand in the dish; not even lifting it to the mouth.

25.verse: Beat a scoffer and the naive learn a lesson; rebuke the intelligent and they gain knowledge.

26.verse: Whoever mistreats a father or drives away a mother, is a shameless and disgraceful child.

27.verse: My son, stop attending to correction; start straying from words of knowledge.

28.verse: An unprincipled witness scoffs at justice, and the mouth of the wicked pours out iniquity.

29.verse: Rods are prepared for scoffers, and blows for the backs of fools.

1.verse: Chapter 20 - Wine is arrogant, strong drink is riotous; none who are intoxicated by them are wise.

2.verse: The terror of a king is like the roar of a lion; those who incur his anger forfeit their lives.

3.verse: A person gains honor by avoiding strife, while every fool starts a quarrel.

4.verse: In seedtime sluggards do not plow; when they look for the harvest, it is not there.

5.verse: The intention of the human heart is deep water, but the intelligent draw it forth.

6.verse: Many say, “My loyal friend,” but who can find someone worthy of trust?

7.verse: The just walk in integrity; happy are their children after them!

8.verse: A king seated on the throne of judgment dispels all evil with his glance.

9.verse: Who can say, “I have made my heart clean, I am cleansed of my sin”?

10.verse: Varying weights, varying measures, are both an abomination to the LORD.

11.verse: In their actions even children can playact though their deeds be blameless and right.

12.verse: The ear that hears, the eye that sees— the LORD has made them both.

13.verse: Do not love sleep lest you be reduced to poverty; keep your eyes open, have your fill of food.

14.verse: “Bad, bad!” says the buyer, then goes away only to boast.

15.verse: One can put on gold and abundant jewels, but wise lips are the most precious ornament.

16.verse: Take the garment of the one who became surety for a stranger; if for foreigners, exact the pledge!

17.verse: Bread earned by deceit is sweet, but afterward the mouth is filled with gravel.

18.verse: Plans made with advice succeed; with wise direction wage your war.

19.verse: A slanderer reveals secrets; so have nothing to do with a babbler!

20.verse: Those who curse father or mother— their lamp will go out in the dead of night.

21.verse: Possessions greedily guarded at the outset will not be blessed in the end.

22.verse: Do not say, “I will repay evil!” Wait for the LORD, who will help you.

23.verse: Varying weights are an abomination to the LORD, and false scales are not good.

24.verse: Our steps are from the LORD; how, then, can mortals understand their way?

25.verse: It is a trap to pledge rashly a sacred gift, and after a vow, then to reflect.

26.verse: A wise king winnows the wicked, and threshes them under the cartwheel.

27.verse: A lamp from the LORD is human life-breath; it searches through the inmost being.

28.verse: His steadfast loyalty safeguards the king, and he upholds his throne by justice.

29.verse: The glory of the young is their strength, and the dignity of the old is gray hair.

30.verse: Evil is cleansed away by bloody lashes, and a scourging to the inmost being.

1.verse: Chapter 21 - A king’s heart is channeled water in the hand of the LORD; God directs it where he pleases.

2.verse: All your ways may be straight in your own eyes, but it is the LORD who weighs hearts.

3.verse: To do what is right and just is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.

4.verse: Haughty eyes and a proud heart— the lamp of the wicked will fail.

5.verse: The plans of the diligent end in profit, but those of the hasty end in loss.

6.verse: Trying to get rich by lying is chasing a bubble over deadly snares.

7.verse: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away, because they refuse to do what is right.

8.verse: One’s path may be winding and unfamiliar, but one’s conduct is blameless and right.

9.verse: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop than in a mansion with a quarrelsome woman.

10.verse: The soul of the wicked desires evil; their neighbor finds no pity in their eyes.

11.verse: When scoffers are punished the naive become wise; when the wise succeed, they gain knowledge.

12.verse: The Righteous One appraises the house of the wicked, bringing down the wicked to ruin.

13.verse: Those who shut their ears to the cry of the poor will themselves call out and not be answered.

14.verse: A secret gift allays anger, and a present concealed, violent wrath.

15.verse: When justice is done it is a joy for the just, downfall for evildoers.

16.verse: Whoever strays from the way of good sense will abide in the assembly of the shades.

17.verse: The lover of pleasure will suffer want; the lover of wine and perfume will never be rich.

18.verse: The wicked serve as ransom for the just, and the faithless for the upright.

19.verse: It is better to dwell in a wilderness than with a quarrelsome wife and trouble.

20.verse: Precious treasure and oil are in the house of the wise, but the fool consumes them.

21.verse: Whoever pursues justice and kindness will find life and honor.

22.verse: The wise person storms the city of the mighty, and overthrows the stronghold in which they trust.

23.verse: Those who guard mouth and tongue guard themselves from trouble.

24.verse: Proud, boastful—scoffer is the name: those who act with overbearing pride.

25.verse: The desire of sluggards will slay them, for their hands refuse to work.

26.verse: Some are consumed with avarice all the day, but the just give unsparingly.

27.verse: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination, the more so when they offer it with bad intent.

28.verse: The false witness will perish, but one who listens will give lasting testimony.

29.verse: The face of the wicked hardens, but the upright maintains a straight course.

30.verse: No wisdom, no understanding, no counsel prevail against the LORD.

31.verse: The horse is equipped for the day of battle, but victory is the LORD’s.

1.verse: Chapter 22 - A good name is more desirable than great riches, and high esteem, than gold and silver.

2.verse: Rich and poor have a common bond: the LORD is the maker of them all.

3.verse: The astute see an evil and hide, while the naive continue on and pay the penalty.

4.verse: The result of humility and fear of the LORD is riches, honor and life.

5.verse: Thorns and snares are on the path of the crooked; those who would safeguard their lives will avoid them.

6.verse: Train the young in the way they should go; even when old, they will not swerve from it.

7.verse: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is the slave of the lender.

8.verse: Those who sow iniquity reap calamity, and the rod used in anger will fail.

9.verse: The generous will be blessed, for they share their food with the poor.

10.verse: Expel the arrogant and discord goes too; strife and insult cease.

11.verse: The LORD loves the pure of heart; the person of winning speech has a king for a friend.

12.verse: The eyes of the LORD watch over the knowledgeable, but he defeats the projects of the faithless.

13.verse: The sluggard says, “A lion is outside; I might be slain in the street.”

14.verse: The mouth of the foreign woman is a deep pit; whoever incurs the LORD’s anger will fall into it.

15.verse: Folly is bound to the heart of a youth, but the rod of discipline will drive it out.

16.verse: Oppressing the poor for enrichment, giving to the rich: both are sheer loss.

17.verse: IV. Sayings of the Wise - The Words of the Wise: Incline your ear, and hear my words, and let your mind attend to my teaching;

18.verse: For it will be well if you hold them within you, if they all are ready on your lips.

19.verse: That your trust may be in the LORD, I make them known to you today—yes, to you.

20.verse: Have I not written for you thirty sayings, containing counsels and knowledge,

21.verse: To teach you truly how to give a dependable report to one who sends you?

22.verse: Do not rob the poor because they are poor, nor crush the needy at the gate;

23.verse: For the LORD will defend their cause, and will plunder those who plunder them.

24.verse: Do not be friendly with hotheads, nor associate with the wrathful,

25.verse: Lest you learn their ways, and become ensnared.

26.verse: Do not be one of those who give their hand in pledge, those who become surety for debts;

27.verse: For if you are unable to pay, your bed will be taken from under you.

28.verse: Do not remove the ancient landmark that your ancestors set up.

29.verse: Do you see those skilled at their work? They will stand in the presence of kings, but not in the presence of the obscure.

1.verse: Chapter 23 - When you sit down to dine with a ruler, mark well the one who is before you;

2.verse: Stick the knife in your gullet if you have a ravenous appetite.

3.verse: Do not desire his delicacies; it is food that deceives.

4.verse: Do not wear yourself out to gain wealth, cease to be worried about it;

5.verse: When your glance flits to it, it is gone! For assuredly it grows wings, like the eagle that flies toward heaven.

6.verse: Do not take food with unwilling hosts, and do not desire their delicacies;

7.verse: For like something stuck in the throat is that food. “Eat and drink,” they say to you, but their hearts are not with you;

8.verse: The little you have eaten you will vomit up, and you will have wasted your agreeable words.

9.verse: Do not speak in the hearing of fools; they will despise the wisdom of your words.

10.verse: Do not remove the ancient landmark, nor invade the fields of the fatherless;

11.verse: For their redeemer is strong; he will defend their cause against you.

12.verse: Apply your heart to instruction, and your ear to words of knowledge.

13.verse: Do not withhold discipline from youths; if you beat them with the rod, they will not die.

14.verse: Beat them with the rod, and you will save them from Sheol.

15.verse: My son, if your heart is wise, my heart also will rejoice;

16.verse: And my inmost being will exult, when your lips speak what is right.

17.verse: Do not let your heart envy sinners, but only those who always fear the LORD;

18.verse: For you will surely have a future, and your hope will not be cut off.

19.verse: Hear, my son, and be wise, and guide your heart in the right way.

20.verse: Do not join with wine bibbers, nor with those who glut themselves on meat.

21.verse: For drunkards and gluttons come to poverty, and lazing about clothes one in rags.

22.verse: Listen to your father who begot you, do not despise your mother when she is old.

23.verse: Buy truth and do not sell: wisdom, instruction, understanding!

24.verse: The father of a just person will exult greatly; whoever begets a wise son will rejoice in him.

25.verse: Let your father and mother rejoice; let her who bore you exult.

26.verse: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes keep to my ways,

27.verse: For the harlot is a deep pit, and the foreign woman a narrow well;

28.verse: Yes, she lies in wait like a robber, and increases the number of the faithless.

29.verse: Who scream? Who shout? Who have strife? Who have anxiety? Who have wounds for nothing? Who have bleary eyes?

30.verse: Whoever linger long over wine, whoever go around quaffing wine.

31.verse: Do not look on the wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup. It goes down smoothly,

32.verse: but in the end it bites like a serpent, and stings like an adder.

33.verse: Your eyes behold strange sights, and your heart utters incoherent things;

34.verse: You are like one sleeping on the high seas, sprawled at the top of the mast.

35.verse: “They struck me, but it did not pain me; they beat me, but I did not feel it. When can I get up, when can I go out and get more?”

1.verse: Chapter 24 - Do not envy the wicked, nor desire to be with them;

2.verse: For their hearts plot violence, and their lips speak of foul play.

3.verse: By wisdom a house is built, by understanding it is established;

4.verse: And by knowledge its rooms are filled with every precious and pleasing possession.

5.verse: The wise are more powerful than the strong, and the learned, than the mighty,

6.verse: For by strategy war is waged, and victory depends on many counselors.

7.verse: Wise words are beyond fools’ reach, in the assembly they do not open their mouth;

8.verse: As they calculate how to do evil, people brand them troublemakers.

9.verse: The scheme of a fool gains no acceptance, the scoffer is an abomination to the community.

10.verse: Did you fail in a day of adversity, did your strength fall short?

11.verse: Did you fail to rescue those who were being dragged off to death, those tottering, those near death,

12.verse: because you said, “We didn’t know about it”? Surely, the Searcher of hearts knows and will repay all according to their deeds.

13.verse: If you eat honey, my son, because it is good, if pure honey is sweet to your taste,

14.verse: Such, you must know, is wisdom to your soul. If you find it, you will have a future, and your hope will not be cut off.

15.verse: Do not lie in wait at the abode of the just, do not ravage their dwelling places;

16.verse: Though the just fall seven times, they rise again, but the wicked stumble from only one mishap.

17.verse: Do not rejoice when your enemies fall, and when they stumble, do not let your heart exult,

18.verse: Lest the LORD see it, be displeased with you, and withdraw his wrath from your enemies.

19.verse: Do not be provoked at evildoers, do not envy the wicked;

20.verse: For the evil have no future, the lamp of the wicked will be put out.

21.verse: My son, fear the LORD and the king; have nothing to do with those who hate them;

22.verse: For disaster will issue suddenly, and calamity from them both, who knows when?

23.verse: V. Further Sayings of the Wise - These also are Words of the Wise: To show partiality in judgment is not good.

24.verse: Whoever says to the guilty party, “You are innocent,” will be cursed by nations, scorned by peoples;

25.verse: But those who render just verdicts will fare well, and on them will come the blessing of prosperity.

26.verse: An honest reply— a kiss on the lips.

27.verse: Complete your outdoor tasks, and arrange your work in the field; afterward you can build your house.

28.verse: Do not testify falsely against your neighbor and so deceive with your lips.

29.verse: Do not say, “As they did to me, so will I do to them; I will repay them according to their deeds.”

30.verse: I passed by the field of a sluggard, by the vineyard of one with no sense;

31.verse: It was all overgrown with thistles; its surface was covered with nettles, and its stone wall broken down.

32.verse: As I gazed at it, I reflected; I saw and learned a lesson:

33.verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest—

34.verse: Then poverty will come upon you like a robber, and want like a brigand.

1.verse: VI. Second Solomonic Collection, Collected Under King Hezekiah Chapter 25 - These also are proverbs of Solomon. The servants of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transmitted them.

2.verse: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter, and the glory of kings to fathom a matter.

3.verse: Like the heavens in height, and the earth in depth, the heart of kings is unfathomable.

4.verse: Remove the dross from silver, and it comes forth perfectly purified;

5.verse: Remove the wicked from the presence of the king, and his throne is made firm through justice.

6.verse: Claim no honor in the king’s presence, nor occupy the place of superiors;

7.verse: For it is better to be told, “Come up closer!” than to be humbled before the prince.

8.verse: What your eyes have seen do not bring forth too quickly against an opponent; For what will you do later on when your neighbor puts you to shame?

9.verse: Argue your own case with your neighbor, but the secrets of others do not disclose;

10.verse: Lest, hearing it, they reproach you, and your ill repute never ceases.

11.verse: Golden apples in silver settings are words spoken at the proper time.

12.verse: A golden earring or a necklace of fine gold— one who gives wise reproof to a listening ear.

13.verse: Like the coolness of snow in the heat of the harvest are faithful messengers for those who send them, lifting the spirits of their masters.

14.verse: Clouds and wind but no rain— the one who boasts of a gift not given.

15.verse: By patience is a ruler persuaded, and a soft tongue can break a bone.

16.verse: If you find honey, eat only what you need, lest you have your fill and vomit it up.

17.verse: Let your foot be seldom in your neighbors’ house, lest they have their fill of you—and hate you.

18.verse: A club, sword, or sharp arrow— the one who bears false witness against a neighbor.

19.verse: A bad tooth or an unsteady foot— a trust betrayed in time of trouble.

20.verse: Like the removal of clothes on a cold day, or vinegar on soda, is the one who sings to a troubled heart.

21.verse: If your enemies are hungry, give them food to eat, if thirsty, give something to drink;

22.verse: For live coals you will heap on their heads, and the LORD will vindicate you.

23.verse: The north wind brings rain, and a backbiting tongue, angry looks.

24.verse: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop than in a mansion with a quarrelsome wife.

25.verse: Cool water to one faint from thirst is good news from a far country.

26.verse: A trampled fountain or a polluted spring— a just person fallen before the wicked.

27.verse: To eat too much honey is not good; nor to seek honor after honor.

28.verse: A city breached and left defenseless are those who do not control their temper.

1.verse: Chapter 26 - Like snow in summer, like rain in harvest, honor for a fool is out of place.

2.verse: Like the sparrow in its flitting, like the swallow in its flight, a curse uncalled-for never lands.

3.verse: The whip for the horse, the bridle for the ass, and the rod for the back of fools.

4.verse: Do not answer fools according to their folly, lest you too become like them.

5.verse: Answer fools according to their folly, lest they become wise in their own eyes.

6.verse: Those who send messages by a fool cut off their feet; they drink down violence.

7.verse: A proverb in the mouth of a fool hangs limp, like crippled legs.

8.verse: Giving honor to a fool is like entangling a stone in the sling.

9.verse: A thorn stuck in the hand of a drunkard is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

10.verse: An archer wounding all who pass by is anyone who hires a drunken fool.

11.verse: As dogs return to their vomit, so fools repeat their folly.

12.verse: You see those who are wise in their own eyes? There is more hope for fools than for them.

13.verse: The sluggard says, “There is a lion in the street, a lion in the middle of the square!”

14.verse: The door turns on its hinges and sluggards, on their beds.

15.verse: The sluggard buries a hand in the dish, too weary to lift it to the mouth.

16.verse: In their own eyes sluggards are wiser than seven who answer with good judgment.

17.verse: Whoever meddles in the quarrel of another is one who grabs a passing dog by the ears.

18.verse: Like a crazed archer scattering firebrands and deadly arrows,

19.verse: Such are those who deceive their neighbor, and then say, “I was only joking.”

20.verse: Without wood the fire dies out; without a talebearer strife subsides.

21.verse: Charcoal for coals, wood for fire— such are the quarrelsome, enkindling strife.

22.verse: The words of a talebearer are like dainty morsels: they sink into one’s inmost being.

23.verse: Like a glazed finish on earthenware are smooth lips and a wicked heart.

24.verse: With their lips enemies pretend, but inwardly they maintain deceit;

25.verse: When they speak graciously, do not trust them, for seven abominations are in their hearts.

26.verse: Hatred can be concealed by pretense, but malice will be revealed in the assembly.

27.verse: Whoever digs a pit falls into it; and a stone comes back upon the one who rolls it.

28.verse: The lying tongue is its owner’s enemy, and the flattering mouth works ruin.

1.verse: Chapter 27 - Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what any day may bring forth.

2.verse: Let another praise you, not your own mouth; a stranger, not your own lips.

3.verse: Stone is heavy, and sand a burden, but a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.

4.verse: Anger is cruel, and wrath overwhelming, but before jealousy who can stand?

5.verse: Better is an open rebuke than a love that remains hidden.

6.verse: Trustworthy are the blows of a friend, dangerous, the kisses of an enemy.

7.verse: One who is full spurns honey; but to the hungry, any bitter thing is sweet.

8.verse: Like a bird far from the nest so is anyone far from home.

9.verse: Perfume and incense bring joy to the heart, but by grief the soul is torn asunder.

10.verse: Do not give up your own friend and your father’s friend; do not resort to the house of your kindred when trouble strikes. Better a neighbor near than kin far away.

11.verse: Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart, so that I can answer whoever taunts me.

12.verse: The astute see an evil and hide; the naive continue on and pay the penalty.

13.verse: Take the garment of the one who became surety for a stranger; if for a foreign woman, exact the pledge!

14.verse: Those who greet their neighbor with a loud voice in the early morning, a curse can be laid to their charge.

15.verse: For a persistent leak on a rainy day the match is a quarrelsome wife;

16.verse: Whoever would hide her hides a stormwind and cannot tell north from south.

17.verse: Iron is sharpened by iron; one person sharpens another.

18.verse: Those who tend a fig tree eat its fruit; so those attentive to their master will be honored.

19.verse: As face mirrors face in water, so the heart reflects the person.

20.verse: Sheol and Abaddon can never be satisfied; so the eyes of mortals can never be satisfied.

21.verse: The crucible for silver, the furnace for gold, so you must assay the praise you receive.

22.verse: Though you pound fools with a pestle, their folly never leaves them.

23.verse: Take good care of your flocks, give careful attention to your herds;

24.verse: For wealth does not last forever, nor even a crown from age to age.

25.verse: When the grass comes up and the new growth appears, and the mountain greens are gathered in,

26.verse: The lambs will provide you with clothing, and the goats, the price of a field,

27.verse: And there will be ample goat’s milk for your food, food for your house, sustenance for your maidens.

1.verse: Chapter 28 - The wicked flee though none pursue; but the just, like a lion, are confident.

2.verse: If a land is rebellious, its princes will be many; but with an intelligent and wise ruler there is stability.

3.verse: One who is poor and extorts from the lowly is a devastating rain that leaves no food.

4.verse: Those who abandon instruction praise the wicked, but those who keep instruction oppose them.

5.verse: The evil understand nothing of justice, but those who seek the LORD understand everything.

6.verse: Better to be poor and walk in integrity than rich and crooked in one’s ways.

7.verse: Whoever heeds instruction is a wise son, but whoever joins with wastrels disgraces his father.

8.verse: Whoever amasses wealth by interest and overcharge gathers it for the one who is kind to the poor.

9.verse: Those who turn their ears from hearing instruction, even their prayer is an abomination.

10.verse: Those who mislead the upright into an evil way will themselves fall into their own pit, but the blameless will attain prosperity.

11.verse: The rich are wise in their own eyes, but the poor who are intelligent see through them.

12.verse: When the just triumph, there is great glory; but when the wicked prevail, people hide.

13.verse: Those who conceal their sins do not prosper, but those who confess and forsake them obtain mercy.

14.verse: Happy those who always fear; but those who harden their hearts fall into evil.

15.verse: A roaring lion or a ravenous bear is a wicked ruler over a poor people.

16.verse: The less prudent the rulers, the more oppressive their deeds. Those who hate ill-gotten gain prolong their days.

17.verse: Though a person burdened with blood guilt is in flight even to the grave, let no one offer support.

18.verse: Whoever walks blamelessly is safe, but one whose ways are crooked falls into a pit.

19.verse: Those who cultivate their land will have plenty of food, but those who engage in idle pursuits will have plenty of want.

20.verse: The trustworthy will be richly blessed; but whoever hastens to be rich will not go unpunished.

21.verse: To show partiality is never good: for even a morsel of bread one may do wrong.

22.verse: Misers hurry toward wealth, not knowing that want is coming toward them.

23.verse: Whoever rebukes another wins more favor than one who flatters with the tongue.

24.verse: Whoever defrauds father or mother and says, “It is no sin,” is a partner to a brigand.

25.verse: The greedy person stirs up strife, but the one who trusts in the LORD will prosper.

26.verse: Those who trust in themselves are fools, but those who walk in wisdom are safe.

27.verse: Those who give to the poor have no lack, but those who avert their eyes, many curses.

28.verse: When the wicked prevail, people hide; but at their fall the just abound.

1.verse: Chapter 29 - Those stiff-necked in the face of reproof in an instant will be shattered beyond cure.

2.verse: When the just flourish, the people rejoice; but when the wicked rule, the people groan.

3.verse: Whoever loves wisdom gives joy to his father, but whoever consorts with harlots squanders his wealth.

4.verse: By justice a king builds up the land; but one who raises taxes tears it down.

5.verse: Those who speak flattery to their neighbor cast a net at their feet.

6.verse: The sin of the wicked is a trap, but the just run along joyfully.

7.verse: The just care for the cause of the poor; the wicked do not understand such care.

8.verse: Scoffers enflame the city, but the wise calm the fury.

9.verse: If a wise person disputes with a fool, there is railing and ridicule but no resolution.

10.verse: The bloodthirsty hate the blameless, but the upright seek his life.

11.verse: Fools give vent to all their anger; but the wise, biding their time, control it.

12.verse: If rulers listen to lying words, their servants all become wicked.

13.verse: The poor and the oppressor meet: the LORD gives light to the eyes of both.

14.verse: If a king is honestly for the rights of the poor, his throne stands firm forever.

15.verse: The rod of correction gives wisdom, but uncontrolled youths disgrace their mothers.

16.verse: When the wicked increase, crime increases; but the just will behold their downfall.

17.verse: Discipline your children, and they will bring you comfort, and give delight to your soul.

18.verse: Without a vision the people lose restraint; but happy is the one who follows instruction.

19.verse: Not by words alone can servants be trained; for they understand but do not respond.

20.verse: Do you see someone hasty in speech? There is more hope for a fool!

21.verse: If servants are pampered from childhood they will turn out to be stubborn.

22.verse: The ill-tempered stir up strife, and the hotheaded cause many sins.

23.verse: Haughtiness brings humiliation, but the humble of spirit acquire honor.

24.verse: Partners of a thief hate themselves; they hear the imprecation but do not testify.

25.verse: Fear of others becomes a snare, but the one who trusts in the LORD is safe.

26.verse: Many curry favor with a ruler, but it is from the LORD that one receives justice.

27.verse: An abomination to the just, the evildoer; an abomination to the wicked, one whose way is straight.

1.verse: VII. Sayings of Agur and Others Chapter 30 - The words of Agur, son of Jakeh the Massaite: The pronouncement of mortal man: “I am weary, O God; I am weary, O God, and I am exhausted.

2.verse: I am more brute than human being, without even human intelligence;

3.verse: Neither have I learned wisdom, nor have I the knowledge of the Holy One.

4.verse: Who has gone up to heaven and come down again— who has cupped the wind in the hollow of the hand? Who has bound up the waters in a cloak— who has established all the ends of the earth? What is that person’s name, or the name of his son?”

5.verse: Every word of God is tested; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.

6.verse: Add nothing to his words, lest he reprimand you, and you be proved a liar.

7.verse: Two things I ask of you, do not deny them to me before I die:

8.verse: Put falsehood and lying far from me, give me neither poverty nor riches; provide me only with the food I need;

9.verse: Lest, being full, I deny you, saying, “Who is the LORD?” Or, being in want, I steal, and profane the name of my God.

10.verse: Do not criticize servants to their master, lest they curse you, and you have to pay the penalty.

11.verse: There are some who curse their fathers, and do not bless their mothers.

12.verse: There are some pure in their own eyes, yet not cleansed of their filth.

13.verse: There are some—how haughty their eyes! how overbearing their glance!

14.verse: There are some—their teeth are swords, their teeth are knives, Devouring the needy from the earth, and the poor from the human race.

15.verse: The leech has two daughters: “Give,” and “Give.” Three things never get their fill, four never say, “Enough!”

16.verse: Sheol, a barren womb, land that never gets its fill of water, and fire, which never says, “Enough!”

17.verse: The eye that mocks a father, or scorns the homage due a mother, Will be plucked out by brook ravens; devoured by a brood of vultures.

18.verse: Three things are too wonderful for me, yes, four I cannot understand:
