19.verse: The way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a serpent upon a rock, The way of a ship on the high seas, and the way of a man with a woman.

20.verse: This is the way of an adulterous woman: she eats, wipes her mouth, and says, “I have done no wrong.”

21.verse: Under three things the earth trembles, yes, under four it cannot bear up:

22.verse: Under a slave who becomes king, and a fool who is glutted with food;

23.verse: Under an unloved woman who is wed, and a maidservant who displaces her mistress.

24.verse: Four things are among the smallest on the earth, and yet are exceedingly wise:

25.verse: Ants—a species not strong, yet they store up their food in the summer;

26.verse: Badgers—a species not mighty, yet they make their home in the crags;

27.verse: Locusts—they have no king, yet they march forth in formation;

28.verse: Lizards—you can catch them with your hands, yet they find their way into kings’ palaces.

29.verse: Three things are stately in their stride, yes, four are stately in their carriage:

30.verse: The lion, mightiest of beasts, retreats before nothing;

31.verse: The strutting cock, and the he-goat, and the king at the head of his people.

32.verse: If you have foolishly been proud or presumptuous—put your hand on your mouth;

33.verse: For as the churning of milk produces curds, and the pressing of the nose produces blood, the churning of anger produces strife.

1.verse: VIII. Sayings of King Lemuel Chapter 31 - The words of Lemuel, king of Massa, the instruction his mother taught him:

2.verse: What are you doing, my son! what are you doing, son of my womb; what are you doing, son of my vows!

3.verse: Do not give your vigor to women, or your strength to those who ruin kings.

4.verse: It is not for kings, Lemuel, not for kings to drink wine; strong drink is not for princes,

5.verse: Lest in drinking they forget what has been decreed, and violate the rights of any who are in need.

6.verse: Give strong drink to anyone who is perishing, and wine to the embittered;

7.verse: When they drink, they will forget their misery, and think no more of their troubles.

8.verse: Open your mouth in behalf of the mute, and for the rights of the destitute;

9.verse: Open your mouth, judge justly, defend the needy and the poor!

10.verse: IX. Poem on the Woman of Worth - Who can find a woman of worth? Far beyond jewels is her value.

11.verse: Her husband trusts her judgment; he does not lack income.

12.verse: She brings him profit, not loss, all the days of her life.

13.verse: She seeks out wool and flax and weaves with skillful hands.

14.verse: Like a merchant fleet, she secures her provisions from afar.

15.verse: She rises while it is still night, and distributes food to her household, a portion to her maidservants.

16.verse: She picks out a field and acquires it; from her earnings she plants a vineyard.

17.verse: She girds herself with strength; she exerts her arms with vigor.

18.verse: She enjoys the profit from her dealings; her lamp is never extinguished at night.

19.verse: She puts her hands to the distaff, and her fingers ply the spindle.

20.verse: She reaches out her hands to the poor, and extends her arms to the needy.

21.verse: She is not concerned for her household when it snows— all her charges are doubly clothed.

22.verse: She makes her own coverlets; fine linen and purple are her clothing.

23.verse: Her husband is prominent at the city gates as he sits with the elders of the land.

24.verse: She makes garments and sells them, and stocks the merchants with belts.

25.verse: She is clothed with strength and dignity, and laughs at the days to come.

26.verse: She opens her mouth in wisdom; kindly instruction is on her tongue.

27.verse: She watches over the affairs of her household, and does not eat the bread of idleness.

28.verse: Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband, too, praises her:

29.verse: “Many are the women of proven worth, but you have excelled them all.”

30.verse: Charm is deceptive and beauty fleeting; the woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.

31.verse: Acclaim her for the work of her hands, and let her deeds praise her at the city gates.
